Beware of this Aldi scam offering you free ÂŁ65 vouchers towards your shopping (Picture: Shutterstock) If you shop at Aldi, beware of this scam which could trick you into thinking you’re saving money.Â 
Anger over Aldi crisps that contain as few as two per pack The German retailer said that ÂŁ65 vouchers which have been circulating on Facebook and Twitter are fake and will not be accepted at any of their stores.
The chain has launched an investigation into the scam and and is urging customers not to share their personal details when claiming the ‘vouchers’.

Writing on Twitter, Aldi said: ‘We are aware that there is a hoax ÂŁ65 Aldi voucher being circulated. This voucher is fraudulent and cannot be redeemed in store.â€
‘Aldi UK will never ask you to share your personal details via a website to redeem a genuine voucher offer. This is being investigated.’
Last year, people were being offered a fake ÂŁ85 Aldi voucher supposedly to mark the Aldi’s 55th anniversary (Picture: Facebook) It is unclear how many people have been affected by the scam as of yet but it isn’t the first time fraudsters have targeted the supermarket.

Those who clicked through to the ‘survey page’ were then struck with malware and viruses on their computers.
How to spot a fake email message and keep safe against them If you receive an email supposedly from a major organisation and it asks you for personal information, do not respond. Especially if your security details such as your PIN or full password is being asked. Choose strong passwords so it’s harder to beÂ hacked and change them every 90 days. If you’re prompted to download software, don’t – it may have a virus. 
Mark James, security specialist at ESET, that offers anti-virus products, said the scams had been around for a while and showed no sign of disappearing.
He said: ‘There tends to be a high degree of success, if they never worked they would not still be doing the rounds which proves that generally we are not learning and continuing to fall foul of these types of attacks.’
